messages: I’m Mia, your automated Medical Information Assistant from the Pediatric Mendelian Genomics Research Center (PMGRC) through Children’s National, UC Irvine, and Invitae.
I’m here to tell you all about the PMGRC study and help you decide if you want to participate.
👋 Hi Mia!
I’m going to provide details about the study like why we are doing this research, what you will be expected to do if you enroll, and possible risks and benefits.
My job is to give you plenty of information to help you choose whether or not to participate.
Great!
This chat usually takes about 30 minutes to go through before you can sign the consent form to enroll at the end.
You can always pause and come back at a later point.
At any time during our conversation, you can click the menu button (☰) at the top left to find chat options.
If you want to change any of your responses, just click on the response or go to the menu.
Okay
I understand
All of the information I will share is also described in more detail in our consent document.
You can only sign the consent form electronically after reviewing it with me or with a study team member.
You can access an example of the consent document by clicking this link, but please remember to return here to complete our chat.
Can I look at this after we chat?
Yes, you can come back here to access the link later, and I can also provide the link again at the end of the chat.
Okay, great

Whether or not you choose to participate in the study, the team at Children's National may review your interactions with me, Mia, to better understand how people interact with me and how I can improve.
Ok, sounds good
If you are ready, we can start going through the information together right now!
If you would rather review the consent later or you would rather review it with a member of the study team, just let me know!
I’d like to continue chatting with Mia now
I want to pick up this chat with Mia sometime later
I'd prefer to talk to someone from the research team
Okay!
Let’s do this!
Please be sure to take notes and write down any questions you have as we go through this chat, as you will have the option to talk to a study team member at the end. ✏️
If you have any questions that are not answered during this chat, we will put you in touch with a team member to discuss them further.
Okay! No problem.
You can use the link in your text message to come back at any time.
Let me know when you are ready to chat.
Sure thing.
Someone from our study team will contact you directly by phone or email within the next 2-3 weeks.
If you have questions now, you can contact us at PMGRC@childrensnational.org
I'm ready to chat now
Sounds good! 👍
The goal of this study is to help identify the causes of genetic health conditions.
You are being invited to join this study because you or someone in your family has a genetic health condition (or a health issue that might be related to genes).
We often enroll multiple family members (people related by blood) in the study.
Okay
Why only those related by blood?
Having genetic data from blood relatives can help us do a better job of interpreting genetic findings.
For example, if we find a genetic change in a person who has a health issue, it is important to know if this genetic change was passed down through the family.
So, having data from blood-related family members helps us interpret what we find.
Ah, that makes sense
Ideally, we would enroll the person with the genetic health condition as well as both of their biological parents (mom and dad), if possible.
So, if one or both parents are able to enroll, that would be great!
Good to know!
Each person who enrolls in the study will have to go through this study consent process.
You can enroll yourself and/or your children in this chat today, and we can send a separate chat link to any other adults who want to enroll.
Okay
For children who are 6 years old or younger, a parent or guardian can complete the consent on their behalf.
For children ages 7 to 17, (or for adults who are under another person’s legal guardianship), a parent or guardian must complete the official consent.
We will also need to talk directly to the child (if they are capable) to get their agreement about participating.
People who are age 18 or older need to go through the consent process themselves (except those who are under another person’s legal guardianship).
Okay
I understand
Can you tell me who in your family might consider enrolling in this study? (check all that apply, including any parents or other adults who might enroll)
Great!
You can complete the consent process for yourself today in this chat
Okay, thanks
If your child’s other parent or another adult family member is considering enrolling, they should also complete this consent chat themselves.
If they have not already received a link to this consent chat, I can send them one now with just a few pieces of information.
They have already received a link to this chat
I'd like to send them a link to the chat
How many of your children are you considering enrolling?
One child
More than one child
You’re welcome 😀
Now, let’s take a moment to talk a little bit about genetics.
Do you want to keep it simple or get a little more science-y?
Science-y please 🤓
Let's keep it simple
Now, let’s take a moment to talk a little bit about genetics.
Do you want to keep it simple or get a little more science-y?
Okay!
Can you tell me their name and cell phone number and/or email address?
Thank you! We’ll contact them with the information you've provided.
If you have other adult family members who are considering enrolling, please let our study team know by emailing us at PMGRC@childrensnational.org.
Okay, thanks
Okay, great
I was hoping you would say that!
You may already know that your body is made of trillions of cells.
Inside each of these cells is your DNA, which provides the instructions for how our bodies grow and develop.
Ah, okay
Your DNA is made up of a genetic code, which is represented by four letters: A, T, C and G.

A little section of the code might look something like this:

ATGCGCTAGCTCCTAGCTAGCCTAGCTAGCTAACGCTAGCCTCGTAGACTACGATCGCTAAGCTAGC
The code is actually over 3 billion letters long!
That's complicated
Okay, can you please select the ages of your children?
For your child who is under age 7 years, you will have the option to complete their consent and enrollment during our chat today.
Great, thanks!
For your child who is between age 7 and age 17, you will have the option to give your consent for your child to enroll in the study.
But because your child is over age 6, we may also need to talk to them briefly to tell them about the study.
If your child is developmentally not able to communicate, you can let us know when you talk with our study team.
Okay
So, after you complete the consent chat with me, I can help arrange a time for you (and your child) to talk to a member of our study team to finalize your child's enrollment.
That sounds good, thanks
Is your 18+ child still under your legal guardianship?
Yes
No
Individuals who are 18 years or older need to complete this consent chat themselves.
Does your 18+ child already have a unique link to this chat?
Yes
No, can we send them a link?
Sure!
Can you tell me your child's name, cell phone number, and/or email?
Thank you! We'll contact them with the information you've provided.
If you have other adult family members who are considering enrolling, please let our study team know by emailing us at PMGRC@childrensnational.org
Great, thanks!
Okay, then they will be able to use that link to complete the consent chat themselves.
Okay, thanks for letting me know
Okay
After our chat today, you will have the option to give your consent for your child to enroll in the study.
But because your child is over age 18, we may also need to talk to them briefly to tell them about the study.
Okay
So, after you complete the consent chat with me, I can help arrange a time for you (and your child) to talk to a member of our study team to finalize your child's enrollment.
If your child is developmentally not able to communicate, you can let us know when you talk with our study team.
Okay, thanks
You’re welcome 😀
I know! But your cells know how the read this code
The cells use your genetic information like a recipe book
IMAGE
It is organized into specific sections, called genes (just like a recipe book is organized into individual recipes)
This sounds familiar
Tell me more
In a recipe book, each recipe gives instructions for making a different dish
In your cells, each gene provides the instructions for molecules called RNA, and each RNA makes a different protein
IMAGE
That's interesting
These proteins can help your body to do many important things
For example, some proteins build our tissues, like muscles and nerves.  Other proteins help our bodies break down food and make energy
That's cool!
I know, right?
You have 2 copies of each gene - one from each of your parents
The 2 copies work together to make you who you are
IMAGE
Got it
People can have different versions of the same gene. This is what makes each person unique
We call these different versions of a gene “variants”
What is a variant?
Remember how we said your genes are like recipes?
Well, if there are any little typos or slight changes in the recipe, the dish might turn out differently than you expected
A variant is when the letters of the genetic code are out of order or changed in some other way
I see
When a gene has a variant it gives different instructions.
Imagine that you are baking a cake and the recipe tells you to use salt instead of sugar, or strawberries instead of chocolate!
That’s going to affect the cake!
GIF IMAGE
Got it
Okay, sounds good
You may already know that your body is made up of trillions of cells
Inside each of these cells is your DNA, which provides the instructions for our bodies to grow and develop
The DNA is arranged in sections called genes
Okay
This sounds familiar
Genes are a big part of what makes you who you are
In your cells, each gene provides the instructions for molecules called RNA, and each RNA makes a different protein
IMAGE
That's interesting
These proteins can help your body to do many important things
For example, some proteins build our tissues, like muscles and nerves.  Other proteins help our bodies break down food and make energy
Okay
That's cool!
We all have small differences in our genes, which we call "variants"
I see
When a gene has a variant it gives the body different instructions
Got it
Genetic variants are responsible for making us all unique and different
For example, things like eye color are determined by variants in our genes
Sometimes, having a certain genetic variant can lead to health issues
For example, if a person has a variant in a gene that is related to kidney health, then their chance of having kidney disease may increase.
Interesting
That makes sense
When someone has a health issue caused by a genetic change (or “variant”), we call this a genetic disorder
When we suspect that a patient has a genetic disorder, we will often do genetic testing to try and find the change (or variant) that is causing the health issue
In the PMGRC study, we are interested in doing different kinds of genetic testing to take a detailed look at people’s genetic material to look for changes that might explain their health issues
Great
Here's a 1-minute video that talks about one common type of testing, called sequencing
